content.rendered:
Lithium Batteries

Lithium batteries are a type of rechargeable battery that use lithium as the primary component in the electrochemical reaction. These batteries are widely used in portable electronics, electric vehicles (EVs), medical devices, and many other applications due to their high energy density, long cycle life, and lightweight nature.

Here’s a breakdown of the main features and components of lithium batteries:

  1. Chemistry:

    • Lithium-ion (Li-ion): The most common type of lithium battery, where lithium ions move from the anode (negative side) to the cathode (positive side) during discharge, and vice versa during charging.
    • Lithium Polymer (LiPo): A variation of lithium-ion batteries, using a solid or gel-like polymer electrolyte instead of a liquid one, making them lighter and more flexible in shape.
